Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I watched my stepbrother, Eli, tighten his helmet, his skateboard already perched at the top of the steep, cracked ramp behind our house. He grinned at me, eager to show off the new trick he’d been practicing in secret. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from the synagogue group: “We need one more for the minyan. Can you come now? It’s urgent, for a funeral prayer.” My heart thudded. I knew how important it was to make a minyan, especially for a funeral. It was a mitzvah, a sacred obligation, and I’d been raised to never turn away from such a call. But Eli was counting on me to spot him, to be there in case he fell. I could see the nervous excitement in his eyes, and I remembered my promise to Mom to always look out for him. I stood frozen, torn between the pull of my faith and my family, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me, unsure which way to turn.
